To prove (p → q) ∧ (q → r) → (p → r) using intuitionistic logic, we will use the following rules:

1. Modus Ponens (MP): If A and A → B, then B.
2. Implication Introduction (→I): If we can derive B from A, then we can conclude A → B.

We will proceed with a proof by assuming (p → q) ∧ (q → r) and p, and then show that r follows.

Proof:

1. Assume (p → q) ∧ (q → r) (Assumption)
2. p → q (1, ∧-elimination)
3. q → r (1, ∧-elimination)
4. Assume p (Assumption)
5. q (2, 4, MP)
6. r (3, 5, MP)
7. p → r (4-6, →I)
8. (p → q) ∧ (q → r) → (p → r) (1-7, →I)

Thus, using intuitionistic logic, we have proven that (p → q) ∧ (q → r) → (p → r) for any propositions p, q, and r.
